headline: Treaty Principles Bill Overwhelmingly Defeated in Parliament After Divisive Debate
summary: Parliament has overwhelmingly rejected the contentious Principles of the Treaty of Waitangi Bill in a decisive 112-11 vote, bringing a high-profile and divisive political debate to a close. The day also saw the government introduce major new legislation focused on education reform, fast-tracking medicine approvals, and ratifying a new free trade agreement with the United Arab Emirates, alongside heated exchanges during Question Time on Māori-Crown relations.

topicSummaries.topic: Treaty Principles Bill Overwhelmingly Defeated in Second Reading
topicSummaries.content: The ACT Party's Principles of the Treaty of Waitangi Bill was defeated at its second reading by a vote of 112 to 11, with only ACT MPs voting in favour. The bill, which proposed to legislate a specific set of Treaty principles and put them to a public referendum, attracted a record-breaking number of public submissions, the vast majority in opposition. Proponent David Seymour argued the bill would provide constitutional certainty and ensure equal rights for all New Zealanders, confronting what he called the divisive idea of a "partnership between races." Opponents from Labour, the Greens, and Te Pāti Māori condemned the bill as a "grubby little deal" that was divisive and based on a myth of Māori privilege. The government's coalition partners, National and New Zealand First, also voted against the bill, stating that while a debate on the Treaty's role is valid, this bill was a crude and simplistic way to handle a sensitive topic.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon DAVID SEYMOUR (ACT)
keyExchanges.quote: We will continue to fight on for the truth that all Kiwis are equal. Āke, ake, ake.

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon CHRIS HIPKINS (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: This is a grubby little bill, born of a grubby little deal. It has had a colossal impact on the fabric of our nation, and this bill will for ever be a stain on our country.

topicSummaries.topic: Heated Clashes Over Māori-Crown Relations and Education Policy
topicSummaries.content: Question Time saw fiery exchanges over the government's approach to Māori issues. Labour's Willie Jackson repeatedly challenged Minister for Māori Crown Relations, Tama Potaka, on whether relations had improved, citing the disestablishment of the Māori Health Authority and perceived undermining of te reo. In a separate line of questioning, Labour's Willow-Jean Prime grilled Education Minister Erica Stanford on her commitment to honouring Te Tiriti o Waitangi in the education system, particularly regarding proposed legislative changes and the appointment of curriculum advisors. Minister Stanford defended the government's focus on lifting Māori student achievement as the primary way of honouring the Treaty.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Willie Jackson (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: If his Government is focusing on unifying this country, as Christopher Luxon claimed, how does undermining te reo, destroying the Māori Health Authority, and dismissing tikanga achieve that?

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon TAMA POTAKA (National)
keyExchanges.quote: There are a number of steps that this Government is absolutely focused on—for example, getting the economy back on track, and that includes Māori and all New Zealanders delivering better public services...

topicSummaries.topic: Major Education Reform Bill Introduced, Focuses on Achievement and Strike Notices
topicSummaries.content: The government introduced the Education and Training Amendment Bill (No 2), a significant piece of legislation aimed at refocusing the education sector. Minister Erica Stanford outlined key changes, including making educational achievement the "paramount objective" for school boards. The bill also extends the required notice period for teacher unions to strike from three to seven calendar days to minimise disruption for families. Furthermore, it introduces a requirement for universities to protect freedom of expression and for all schools to have an attendance management plan. These changes are part of the government's wider strategy to lift student achievement and attendance.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Willow-Jean Prime (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: Can she reassure the thousands of educators associated with the 13 peak educational bodies that the place of Te Tiriti o Waitangi in education is safe, given that she is downgrading consideration of Te Tiriti o Waitangi through legislation?

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon ERICA STANFORD (National)
keyExchanges.quote: In answer to that question, we're not downgrading it at all... if we're going to honour the Treaty, we need to make sure that our tamariki Māori are achieving in our education system—that has to be the paramount objective.

topicSummaries.topic: Bill to Fast-Track New Zealand-UAE Free Trade Deal Passes First Reading
topicSummaries.content: Legislation to implement New Zealand's new Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement (CEPA) with the United Arab Emirates passed its first reading with broad cross-party support. The government hailed the agreement as its fastest-ever negotiated free-trade deal, which will eliminate tariffs on 98.5% of New Zealand's goods exports to the UAE immediately. The deal also includes chapters on sustainable trade and Indigenous economic cooperation. The Labour Party supported the bill, acknowledging its bipartisan origins. However, the Green Party opposed it, citing concerns over the UAE's human rights record, data sovereignty issues in the digital trade chapter, and a misrepresentation of Te Tiriti o Waitangi in briefing documents.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon SCOTT SIMPSON (National)
keyExchanges.quote: This free-trade agreement (FTA), our first with a Middle Eastern State, will do so, helping to reinforce our flourishing bilateral relationship and grow our economic ties with the UAE.

keyExchanges.speaker: Dr LAWRENCE XU-NAN (Green)
keyExchanges.quote: We must also mention the serious human rights concerns that we have, and the baseline is what values we are able to compromise.

topicSummaries.topic: Bill to Streamline Medicine Approvals Passes First Reading
topicSummaries.content: The Medicines Amendment Bill, designed to give New Zealanders faster access to new medicines, passed its first reading. The legislation proposes a streamlined verification pathway that would allow Medsafe to approve medicines that have already been cleared by at least two trusted overseas regulators, reducing approval times. The National Party stated the bill would lead to better patient outcomes. The Labour Party offered cautious support for the bill to proceed to the select committee stage, but stressed the need to ensure New Zealand's own high safety standards are not compromised and questioned the government's commitment given its removal of free prescriptions.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon PEENI HENARE (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: This particular bill, while it might look towards greater access, we must make sure that it's robust enough to show that New Zealanders can continue to make sure that the medicines that it accesses are the right ones and won't do harm to Kiwis.

keyExchanges.speaker: Dr CARLOS CHEUNG (National)
keyExchanges.quote: Faster access to medicines leads to better patient outcomes. For that, I commend this bill to the House.

conclusion: Parliament decisively rejected a controversial attempt to redefine the Treaty of Waitangi's principles, closing a divisive chapter while the government simultaneously opened new legislative fronts on education, trade, and health.
